DOC.brief_summary: Tissue oxygen saturation is non-invasively measured using near-infrared spectroscopy, by two device, INVOS®(somanetics Corporation, USA ) and InSpectra™ (Hutchinson Technology, USA). Each probes are attached to both thenar muscles and vascular occlusion test (VOT) is performed. The investigators will compare the Invos® data to InSpectra™ to investigate whether tissue oxygen saturation values by INVOS® can substitute for InSpectra™.
DOC.brief_title: Comparison of Two Devices Using Near-infra Red Spectroscopy During a Vascular Occlusion Test
DOC.detailed_description: Tissue oxygen saturation is non-invasively measured using near-infrared spectroscopy, by two device, INVOS®(somanetics Corporation, USA ) and InSpectra™ (Hutchinson Technology, USA). InSpectra™ was introduced later than INVOS®. With InSpectra™, clinicians have used a vascular occlusion test (VOT) to evaluate dynamic changes in tissue oxygen saturation during ischemia and reperfusion, and thus, microcirculatory function. There have been little data about VOT using INVOS®, although it is more popular device. We hypothesized that there would be a difference between the values from INVOS® and InSpectra™. The aim of this study is to evaluate changes in tissue oxygen saturation in the thenar muscle during VOT using INVOS® and comapre it to InSpectra™ in a normal population.
DOC.criteria: healthy subject age under 18 years old with arteriovenous fistula with peripheral vessel disease taking vasoactive drug with a skin ailment with HTN, DM with diagnosed heart disease
